conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (D or E) liquid will flow into after passing through baffles from sources A, B, and C.
The image shows three liquid sources (A, B, C) at the top, various angled baffles in the middle, and two containers (D and E) at the bottom.
The second and third images depict the actual flow paths of the liquid when released.
Liquid from A starts at the top left (orange source).
Liquid from A flows downward and encounters the first orange diagonal baffle.
Following the baffle, liquid from A gets redirected toward the bottom left.
In the second image, liquid from A connects with the yellow path.
Following the flow path in the third image, liquid from A eventually connects to a series of baffles that lead to container D (left).
Liquid from B starts from the blue source in the middle-top.
Liquid from B flows downward and encounters the yellow diagonal baffle.
In the second image, the blue path flows along the yellow baffle.
In the third image, the blue flow continues down, connects with a new path, and ultimately reaches the gray horizontal baffle.
After the gray baffle, liquid from B appears to flow toward container E (right).
Liquid from C starts from the orange source on the top right.
Liquid from C flows straight down in the second image.
In the third image, liquid from C connects with the blue path.
Eventually, liquid from C merges with the flow heading toward container E (right).
Liquid from A flows through multiple baffles and reaches container D (left).
Liquid from B follows a path that eventually leads to container E (right).
Liquid from C flows downward, merges with other flows, and reaches container E (right).
Liquid from A will flow into container D, and liquids from B and C will both flow into container E.
